ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Close-reading of a diverse selection of texts

I really enjoyed the texts that Professor Warner chose for his section of ENGL 127, and I felt the class lived up to its title not in the typical way that one might conceptualize the phrase "American literature" (a white, male, centuries-old canon), but through a combination of texts that highlighted numerous facets and evolutions of American life and culture. I'm grateful to this course for opening my eyes to the works of Stephen Crane and Flannery O'Connor, while reintroducing me through a collaborative and critical lens to the likes of Morrison, Whitman, Baldwin, etc.
I learned to improve my writing especially in terms of being concise and clear.
I learned important critical reading skills, and expanded my understanding of American literature. I was also able to refine my analytical essay writing abilities.
I think taking this class with Professor Warner made my writing really improve, and I also found everything we read really engaging.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think this course flowed as smoothly as it could've, given the confines of Zoom, and I was always encouraged by the enthusiasm and participation of my fellow classmates. Our weekly reading responses also helped greatly in terms of avoiding lulls in conversation (which Zoom makes, I think, much more frequent).
the discussions for this course were always great.

After the first paper, Prof. Warner goes over it with you line by line, which is incredibly helpful. This doesn't happen at the same level for the other papers, but you still receive feedback. The quality of discussion is very high, and sometimes the seminar could feel disconnected but that was mostly a pandemic virtual thing. I will say that the 2.5 weeks on Moby-Dick is not enough time (at least for a slowish reader like me) to fully absorb the text, and at times during that period I wished that we had delved into 2ish more normal-length novels in greater detail, but I understand the importance of Moby-Dick to American literature.
Though it was hard to have incredibly in depth discussions over zoom, I don't think there are any weaknesses to the course.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: As noted above, the weekly reading responses we wrote, and which helped frame our class discussions, succeeded in preventing virtual discussions from falling flat or enduring long silences. I think this course succeeded as well as it could have within the confines of Zoom.
We were still able to have high-quality discussion about the readings, although the screen discussions can be a bit tiring.
I think Professor Warner did the best that could have been done over zoom.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! This class has a heavy workload of readings, but it is worth encouraging yourself to engage with texts you've likely never read closely before.
Yes: the diversity of literature on this syllabus makes it an exciting course for any student with literary affinities, regardless of whether they're an English major.
If you want to challenge and really push yourself to become a better writer and more astute reader, then yes. Expect to be pushed.

Yes, even if you're not an English major. I'm not, and still had a great time reading some fantastic poetry, novels and short stories. You probably won't enjoy the entire syllabus, but you'll find some authors you love.
I would! Especially if you are interested in American literature. Professor Warner is a great teacher!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
